facts.text: Appeal is Civil Appeal No. 135 of 1951

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 135 of 1951.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave by order dated 21 May 1951

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave granted by the Supreme Court of India by its Order dated the 21st of May, 1951,

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal judgment and order dated 19 February 1951 in Appeal No. 136 of 1950

anchor.surface_text: from the Judgment and Order dated the 19th February, 1951, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Allahabad in Appeal No. 136 of 1950.

facts.text: Case argued on 19 November 1954

anchor.surface_text: 1954. November 19.

facts.text: Appellant made profit of Rs. 11,97,648-11-9 during 1948

anchor.surface_text: During the year 1948 the appellant made a profit of Rs. 11,97,648-11-9.

facts.text: Appellant paid 24 3 per cent dividend on ordinary shares in 1948

anchor.surface_text: It paid 24 3 per cent. dividend on ordinary shares, being the maximum that companyld be paid under the Public Companies Limitation of Dividend Ordinance of 1948

facts.text: Appellant paid workers full share of bonus at annas 4 in a rupee of basic earnings in 1948

anchor.surface_text: and also paid to the workers their full share of bonus at annas 4 in a rupee of their basic earnings.

facts.text: Selling rates for cloth and yarn controlled by Government in 1949, approximately 4 per cent below 1948

anchor.surface_text: During the year 1949 the selling rates for cloth and yarn were companytrolled by the Government and were approximately 4 per cent. below those obtained in 1948.

facts.text: Basic wages increased from 1 December 1948 by order of Government of Uttar Pradesh

anchor.surface_text: The basic wages were increased from the 1st December, 1948, by order of the Government of Uttar Pradesh and the total wages paid were therefore higher than those in the previous year.

facts.text: Indiscipline amongst workers and production suffered in 1949

anchor.surface_text: There was moreover indiscipline amongst the workers and production suffered.

facts.text: Strike in October 1949, mills closed for nearly a month

anchor.surface_text: There was a strike in the month of October and the mills were closed for nearly a month.

facts.text: Management unable to secure cotton resulting in curtailment of working hours in 1949

anchor.surface_text: Further the management were unable to secure companyton which resulted in the curtailment of the working hours.

facts.text: Appellant suffered trading loss of Rs. 5,02,563-1-10 in 1949

anchor.surface_text: As a result of all these circumstances the appellant suffered a trading loss of Rs. 5,02,563-1-10.

facts.text: Rs. 2,50,000 excess reserve for taxation written back in 1949

anchor.surface_text: A sum of Rs. 2,50,000 being the excess reserve for taxation was written back

facts.text: Rs. 10,01,871-13-5 transferred from investment account in 1949

anchor.surface_text: and a sum of Rs. 10,01,871-13-5 being the amount of reserve transferred from the investment account was also brought in.

facts.text: Aggregate sum of Rs. 12,51,871-13-5 brought into balance-sheet by transfers in 1949

anchor.surface_text: An aggregate sum of Rs. 12,51,871-13-5 was thus brought into the balance- sheet by these two transfers.

facts.text: Credit balance of Rs. 7,49,308-11-7 shown as profit for 1949 after deducting trading loss

anchor.surface_text: The trading loss was deducted from this amount leaving a credit balance of Rs. 7,49,308-11-7 and that amount was shown as the profit for the year 1949 in the balance-sheet for that year.

facts.text: Dividend of 243/4 per cent paid to ordinary shareholders in 1949

anchor.surface_text: The balance which had been brought forward from the previous year was added thereto and a dividend of 243/4 per cent. was paid to the ordinary shareholders.

facts.text: Appellant paid ex gratia bonus to workmen at annas 2 per rupee of basic earnings notified on 7 April 1950

anchor.surface_text: The appellant also paid ex gratia to the workmen bonus at the rate of annas 2 per rupee of their basic earnings making it clear by their numberification dated the 7th April, 1950,

facts.text: Bonus payment in 1949 was discretionary and not related to contract of employment

anchor.surface_text: that the directors had sanctioned the payment at that rate in spite of the appellant having suffered a trading loss for the year, that it was being paid entirely at the discretion of the appellant and was number related to or companynected with any companytract of employment of any worker.

facts.text: Secretary of respondent Union petitioned Provincial Conciliation Officer on 4 May 1950 claiming more production in 1949 than 1948 and bonus at annas 4 per rupee

anchor.surface_text: On the 4th May, 1950, the Secretary of the respondent Union petitioned to the Provincial Conciliation Officer Textile that there was more production in 1949 than in 1948, that there was numberreason to hold that the profit in 1949 was less than in the previous year and that the rate of bonus was wrongly reduced and asked that bonus for 1949 should also be paid at the rate of annas 4 per rupee.

facts.text: Industrial dispute referred to Regional Conciliation Board Textile Kanpur

anchor.surface_text: The industrial dispute which thus arose was referred for enquiry and recording of an award to the Regional Conciliation Board Textile , Kanpur.

facts.text: Conciliation Board by majority awarded bonus at annas 4 per rupee

anchor.surface_text: The Conciliation Board by a majority decision repelled the companytention of the appellant and awarded the payment of bonus at annas 4 per rupee.

facts.text: Industrial Court Textiles and Hosiery Kanpur accepted appellant contention, allowed appeal, set aside award

anchor.surface_text: On an appeal taken by the appellant to the Industrial Court Textiles and Hosiery , Kanpur, the Industrial Court accepted the companytention of the appellant, allowed the appeal and set aside the award.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal agreed with Industrial Court on facts and law but allowed respondent appeal on social justice grounds, directed bonus annas 4 per rupee within six weeks

anchor.surface_text: The respondent thereupon appealed to the Labour Appellate Tribunal which substantially agreed with the Industrial Court on questions of fact as well as the general position in law but imported companysiderations of social justice and treating this as a special case where social justice would demand that labour should have bonus for the year where for that very year capital had number only a reasonable return but much in excess of that , allowed the appeal and directed the appellant to pay to the workmen bonus at the rate of annas 4 per rupee within six weeks of their decision.

facts.text: Industrial Court and Labour Appellate Tribunal found trading loss of Rs. 5,02,563-1-10 in 1949

anchor.surface_text: Both the Industrial Court as well as the Labour Appellate Tribunal found as a fact that there was a trading loss of Rs. 5,02,563-1-10 during the year 1949

facts.text: Industrial Court and Labour Appellate Tribunal found dividend distributed after transferring Rs. 12,51,871-13-5 from reserves

anchor.surface_text: and also that the dividend of 243/4 per cent. to the ordinary shareholders was distributed after transferring the aggregate sum of Rs. 12,51,871-13-5 from the reserves.

article 136 should not interfere with the decisions of the tribunals set up by the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947. This contention can be shortly answered by referring to our decision in Bharat Bank Ltd., Delhi v. Employees of the Bharat Bank Ltd., Delhi 1 , where we held that the Industrial Tribunals were tribunals within the meaning of article 136 and further that article 136 has vested in this, Court exceptional and overriding power to interfere where it reaches the conclusion that a person has been dealt with arbitrarily or that a Court or tribunal within the territory of India has not given a fair deal to a litigant.

concepts.interpretation: Court has exceptional and overriding power under Article 136 to interfere if tribunal deals arbitrarily or does not give fair deal.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: be disregarded altogether, in relations between capital and labour. There may be special cases, and we companysider the case before us to be one, wher

anchor.surface_text: The principles for the grant of bonus were discussed and a formula was evolved by the Full Bench of the Labour Appellate Tribunal in Millowners Association, Bombay v. Rashtreeya Mill Mazdoor Sangh, Bombay 2 As both labour and capital contribute to the earnings of the industrial concern, it is fair that labour should derive some benefit, if there is a surplus after meeting prior or necessary charges and the following were prescribed as the first charges on gross profits, viz., Provision for depreciation, Reserves for rehabilitation, A return at 6 per cent. on the paid up capital. A return on the working capital at a lesser rate than the return on paid up capital. The surplus that remained after meeting the aforesaid deductions would be available for distribution as bonus.

concepts.interpretation: First charges on gross profits: depreciation, rehabilitation reserves, 6% on paid-up capital, lesser on working capital; surplus available for bonus.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ervices already  1  317 Mass. 465. rendered gratuitously or for a prescribed companypensation where there is neither express or implied understanding

concepts.unlisted_description: Formula for computing available surplus for bonus after prior charges

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore clear that the claim for bonus can be made by the employees only if as a result of the joint contribution of capital and labour the industrial concern has earned profits. If in any particular year the working of the industrial concern has resulted in loss there is no basis no justification for a demand for bonus. Bonus is not a deferred wage.

concepts.interpretation: Bonus payable only from current year's profits as joint contribution of capital and labour; not if loss; not deferred wage as it would precede dividend.

Even on a winding up of a company the property of the company would be applied in satisfaction of its liabilities pari passu and, unless the articles of association of the company otherwise provided, in distribution amongst the members according to their rights and interest in the company.

concepts.interpretation: Workers have no right, title or interest in reserves or undistributed profits; only shareholders benefit from transfers for dividends; no bonus claim therefrom if current loss.

anchor.surface_text: The primary meaning of the word bonus according to the definition given in the New English Dictionary is A boon or gift over and above what is nominally due as remuneration to the receiver and which is therefore something wholly to the good . This definition was adopted by Stirling J. in In re Eddystone Marine Insurance Co. 1 . Websters International Dictionary defines bonus as something given in addition to what is ordinarily received by or strictly due to the recipient .

concepts.interpretation: Bonus as ex gratia payment, boon or gift beyond what is due; uncertain and depending on circumstances.

The employees would in no event be entitled to any share or interest in the assets and the capital of the company.

concepts.interpretation: On winding up, company assets satisfy liabilities pari passu then to members; employees no share.

anchor.surface_text: The principles for the grant of bonus were discussed and a formula was evolved by the Full Bench of the Labour Appellate Tribunal in Millowners Association, Bombay v. Rashtreeya Mill Mazdoor Sangh, Bombay 2 As both labour and capital contribute to the earnings of the industrial concern, it is fair that labour should derive some benefit, if there is a surplus after meeting prior or necessary charges and the following were prescribed as the first charges on gross profits, viz., Provision for depreciation, Reserves for rehabilitation, A return at 6 per cent. on the paid up capital. A return on the working capital at a lesser rate than the return on paid up capital. The surplus that remained after meeting the aforesaid deductions would be available for distribution as bonus.

If in any particular year the working of the industrial concern has resulted in loss there is no basis no justification for a demand for bonus. Bonus is not a deferred wage.

arguments.claim: Bonus ordinarily determined on current year profits; no universal rule but social justice exception here

anchor.surface_text: As at present advised a claim for bonus which had been rested on profits earned should ordinarily be determined on the basis of the profits earned in the year under claim and that the scale of bonus should be determined on the quantum of profits earned in the year. So, it would follow that if there is trading loss in the year under claim, bonus should not ordinarily be awarded.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: word bonus is number given to it by the objection. It is thus defined by Webster. A premium given for a loan or a charter or other privilege granted

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed on general rule but rejected exception application

holdings.text: If in any particular year the working of the industrial concern has resulted in loss there is no basis no justification for a demand for bonus.

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore clear that the claim for bonus can be made by the employees only if as a result of the joint contribution of -capital and labour the industrial concern has earned profits. If in any particular year the working of the industrial concern has resulted in loss there is no basis no justification for a demand for bonus. Bonus is not a deferred wage.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Full Bench formula of Labour Appellate Tribunal requiring surplus after prior charges on gross profits from joint contribution of capital and labour; trading loss means no profits available.

holdings.text: Bonus is not a deferred wage.

anchor.surface_text: Bonus is not a deferred wage. Because if it were so it would necessarily rank for precedence before dividends The dividends can only be paid out of profits and unless and until profits are made no occasion or question can also arise for distribution of any sum as bonus amongst the employees.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deferred wage would precede dividend, but dividends only from profits; no profits if loss.

holdings.text: The workers not being members of the company would also not have any right, title and interest in the reserves or the undistributed profits which would form part of the assets of the company.

anchor.surface_text: The workers not being members of the company would also not have any right, title and interest in the reserves or the undistributed profits which would form part of the assets of the company. Even on a winding up of a company the property of the company would be applied in satisfaction of its liabilities pari passu and,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Workers not shareholders; reserves benefit shareholders; on winding up, assets to liabilities then members pari passu; no worker share.

holdings.text: Linking of bonus to dividend would obviously create difficulties.

anchor.surface_text: Linking of bonus to dividend would obviously create difficulties. Because if that theory was accepted a company would not declare any dividends but accumulate the profits, build up reserves and distribute those profits in the shape of bonus shares or reduce the capital in which event the workers would not be entitled to claim anything as and by way of bonus.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Would incentivize companies to avoid dividends, accumulate reserves, issue bonus shares or reduce capital, evading bonus claims.

holdings.text: The considerations of social justice imported by the Labour Appellate Tribunal in arriving at the decision in favour of the respondent were not only irrelevant but untenable.

anchor.surface_text: The considerations of social justice imported by the Labour Appellate Tribunal in arriving at the decision in favour of the respondent were not only irrelevant but untenable. Social justice is a very- vague and indeterminate expression and no clear-cut definition can be laid down which will cover all the situations.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Social justice vague, indeterminate; must follow established Full Bench formula; workers contributed to loss via indiscipline and strike.

holdings.text: article 136 has vested in this Court exceptional and overriding power to interfere where it reaches the conclusion that a person has been dealt with arbitrarily or that a Court or tribunal within the territory of India has not given a fair deal to a litigant.

anchor.surface_text: article 136 has vested in this, Court exceptional and overriding power to interfere where it reaches the conclusion that a person has been dealt with arbitrarily or that a Court or tribunal within the territory of India has not given a fair deal to a litigant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Bharat Bank Ltd. precedent; Industrial Tribunals are 'tribunals' under Art 136; interference justified here as LAT arbitrary.

holdings.text: A transfer of moneys from these reserves or the undistributed profits would therefore not enure for the benefit of the workers. The shareholders only would be entitled to such benefit

anchor.surface_text: A transfer of moneys from these reserves or the undistributed profits would therefore not enure for the benefit of the workers. The shareholders only would be entitled to such benefit and the mere fact that dividends were declared and paid to the shareholders out of such reserves and undistributed profits would not entitle the workers to demand bonus when in fact the working of the industrial concern during the particular year had showed a loss.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Transfers to P/L for dividend benefit only shareholders, not workers; no bonus claim therefrom if current year loss.

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore clear that the claim for bonus can be made by the employees only if as a result of the joint contribution of -capital and labour the industrial concern has earned profits. If in any particular year the working of the industrial concern has resulted in loss there is no basis no justification for a demand for bonus. Bonus is not a deferred wage.
The result therefore is that the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal appealed against must be reversed and that of the Industrial Court Textiles and Hosiery , Kanpur, restored.

anchor.surface_text: Bonus is not a deferred wage. Because if it were so it would necessarily rank for precedence before dividends The dividends can only be paid out of profits and unless and until profits are made no occasion or question can also arise for distribution of any sum as bonus amongst the employees.
The result therefore is that the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal appealed against must be reversed and that of the Industrial Court Textiles and Hosiery , Kanpur, restored.

anchor.surface_text: The workers not being members of the company would also not have any right, title and interest in the reserves or the undistributed profits which would form part of the assets of the company. Even on a winding up of a company the property of the company would be applied in satisfaction of its liabilities pari passu and,
The result therefore is that the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal appealed against must be reversed and that of the Industrial Court Textiles and Hosiery , Kanpur, restored.

edges.explanation: h4 directly addresses i3 by stating linking bonus to dividend creates difficulties

anchor.surface_text: Linking of bonus to dividend would obviously create difficulties. Because if that theory was accepted a company would not declare any dividends but accumulate the profits, build up reserves and distribute those profits in the shape of bonus shares or reduce the capital in which event the workers would not be entitled to claim anything as and by way of bonus.
The result therefore is that the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal appealed against must be reversed and that of the Industrial Court Textiles and Hosiery , Kanpur, restored.

edges.explanation: Holding social justice considerations irrelevant untenable addresses issue if they demand bonus despite loss

anchor.surface_text: The considerations of social justice imported by the Labour Appellate Tribunal in arriving at the decision in favour of the respondent were not only irrelevant but untenable. Social justice is a very- vague and indeterminate expression and no clear-cut definition can be laid down which will cover all the situations.
The result therefore is that the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal appealed against must be reversed and that of the Industrial Court Textiles and Hosiery , Kanpur, restored.

anchor.surface_text: article 136 has vested in this, Court exceptional and overriding power to interfere where it reaches the conclusion that a person has been dealt with arbitrarily or that a Court or tribunal within the territory of India has not given a fair deal to a litigant.
The result therefore is that the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal appealed against must be reversed and that of the Industrial Court Textiles and Hosiery , Kanpur, restored.

edges.explanation: Holding h7 states transfers from reserves or undistributed profits do not benefit workers but shareholders, supporting c7 within shared span
h7 concludes that workers get no benefit from reserves or undistributed profits, directly responding to i2

anchor.surface_text: A transfer of moneys from these reserves or the undistributed profits would therefore not enure for the benefit of the workers. The shareholders only would be entitled to such benefit and the mere fact that dividends were declared and paid to the shareholders out of such reserves and undistributed profits would not entitle the workers to demand bonus when in fact the working of the industrial concern during the particular year had showed a loss.
The result therefore is that the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal appealed against must be reversed and that of the Industrial Court Textiles and Hosiery , Kanpur, restored.
